source.bbd148c7:
worldometer_data = worldometer_data.rename(columns = {"Country/Region": "country_region", "Continent": "continent", 
                                                     "Population": "population", "TotalCases": "total_cases", 
                                                      "NewCases": "new_cases", "TotalDeaths": "total_deaths",
                                                      "NewDeaths": "new_deaths", "TotalRecovered": "total_recovered",
                                                     "NewRecovered": "new_recovered", "ActiveCases": "active_cases", 
                                                     "Serious,Critical": "serius_critical", 
                                                      "Tot Cases/1M pop": "top_cases_1m_pop", "Deaths/1M pop": "deaths_1m_pop",

source.e6ec6205:
def plot_population_data(column_1, column_2, number, title, label):
    
    plt.figure(figsize = (12, 6))
    plt.barh(countries_population[column_1].head(number), countries_population[column_2].head(number))
    plt.title(title, size = 15)
    plt.xlabel(label, size = 15)
    plt.yticks(fontsize = 14)
    plt.gca().invert_yaxis()
    plt.show()

                 "Count of People per $Km^2$")

                           "Urban Population Percentage of Highest Populated Countries", "Percentage of Urban Population")

countries_by_tests = worldometer_data.sort_values(by = ["total_tests"], ascending = False).head(10).reset_index(drop = True)
source.e5a2667e:
def plot_tests_bar(feature, value, title, df, size, show = True):
    f, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize = (size * 4, size))
    df = df.sort_values([value], ascending=False).reset_index(drop = True)
    g = sns.barplot(df[feature][0: 10], df[value][0: 10])
    g.set_title(title)
    g.set_ylabel("Number of Tests", size = 13)
    g.set_xlabel("Country", size = 13)
    if show:
        plt.show()
source.c0ea21bb: plot_tests_bar("country_region", "total_tests", "Highest Populated Countries Tests Count", countries_by_population, 4)
source.102d8d57: plot_tests_bar("country_region", "total_tests", "Countries with largest number of tests", countries_by_tests, 4)
source.a21cf0d3:
def plot_who_regions(column, color):
    cases_by_who_regions = worldometer_data.groupby(["who_region"])[column].sum().sort_values(ascending = False)
    
    plt.barh(cases_by_who_regions.index, cases_by_who_regions, color = color)
    plt.title("WHO regions {}".format(column), size = 14)
    plt.xlabel("Cases", size = 14)
    plt.yticks(fontsize = 14)
    plt.gca().invert_yaxis()
    plt.show()

source.7e399ea1:
# Exploring the Spread of the COVID-19 Pandemic
## Author: Viktor Nikolov
source.4dd69244: The recovered list is identical to the confirmed list.
source.d6a621f2: This is not good at all. These are all big countries with a large population and half of them have done very little tests. This indicates that the people who have been infected globally could be more than we realize.
source.e3e2c7ed: The countries/regions with missing data are not in the top 10 list so they can be removed.
source.a48b1b8f: China is missing in ``worldometer_data`` so I am going to add it as an extra row.
source.6be12846: ## Are the countries that are doing more COVID-19 tests handling the situation better
source.9af00a1f: On the deaths list though we have a change. The US is still the country with most death cases but the UK, Italy, France and Spain even though not beeing on the top 10 covid-19 confirmed cases list are in the top 10 covid-19 death cases list. This is quite the change. UK, Italy, France and Spain are actually in the top 50 countries with the largest precentage of older adults list. Italy beeing in second place and France in seventh and the other two not that far behind. We know that older people are more susceptible to the virus so this is a possible answer or atleast a part of the answer to the question why is there such a high death rate in these countries.
source.7a78ffc1: Exept for China and probably UAE the countries who have made the most tests are the ones who are handling the pandemic the worst.
source.b219325f: If I want to use the ``urban_pop_percent`` column I will have to convert it to an integer data type.
source.93f0db52: ## Is the shape of the curve showing us similarities between how different countries deal with the pandemic?

1. Does a larger country population mean more cases of infection and death?
2. Are countries that are doing more virus test's handlying the cituation better?
3. Is the shape of the curve showing us similarities between how different countries deal with the pandemic?

source.db61b58b:
### Introduction
The COVID-19 pandemic is an ongoing global pandemic of coronavirus disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). The outbreak was first identified in December 2019 Wuhan, China. The World Health Organization **(WHO)** declared the outbreak a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on 30 January 2020 and a pandemic on 11 March. In this notebook I will try to explore and answer some questions about the spread of the corona virus and see how different countries delt with the situation.
source.5527abff: Now I'll look at the covid data of the highest populated countries.
source.63e9eed2: We can see that even though all the countries are highly populated there is significant difference in the way different countries control the number of virus cases. China is the highest populated country with a high population density but has almost the least amount of cases and that's not only compared to the largest countries. China is actually becoming famous for being the country that is dealing best with the pandemic. The US on the other hand has a population that is about four times smaller than that of China but the country obviously has no control over it's infection rate.
source.773383f4: I saw previously that even though some countries had a large population they had a very small amount of confirmed cov-19 cases. Now I want to see to what extent is that true. A country can have few cases because it took the right steps to prevent the spread of the virus or because it just didn't do enough cov-19 tests and the data is simply not accurate enough.

source.b847274f: For this question I will be looking at the top 10 most populated countries. I will also want to have a look at their population density and urban population. After that I will look at the confirmed, recovered, active and death COVID-19 cases of those countries. I will compare them with the top 10 contries with most confirmed, death, recovered and active cases globaly and see how many of the highest populated countries are in that list.
source.1f72dd83: Because I will only be working with the top 10 most populated countries I can check if any of the countries containing the ``N.A.`` value are in the top 10 and if not I can remove them.
source.e7b0129d: Not surprisingly the Americas region is the one with most cases of all kind and again unsurprisingly followed by the Europa region. The WesternPacific one being with the least ammount of cases.
